articles.headline: Chicago Police Routinely Trampled on Civil Rights, Justice Dept. Says
articles.snippet: City and federal officials have agreed to a series of reforms the Police Department will make to address the problems detailed in a scathing report.
articles.abstract: City and federal officials have agreed to a series of reforms the Police Department will make to address the problems detailed in a scathing report.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — A blistering report by the Justice Department described far-reaching failures throughout the Chicago Police Department, saying excessive force was rampant, rarely challenged and chiefly aimed at African-Americans and Latinos.
articles.byline: By Julie Bosman and Mitch Smith

articles.headline: 3 Takata Executives Face Criminal Charges Over Exploding Airbags
articles.snippet: U.S. prosecutors charged the executives in a case that involved 11 deaths and instigated the largest automotive recall in American history.
articles.abstract: U.S. prosecutors charged the executives in a case that involved 11 deaths and instigated the largest automotive recall in American history.
articles.lead_paragraph: United States prosecutors said on Friday that they had charged three executives at Takata, the Japanese auto parts maker, with fabricating test data to mask a fatal airbag defect, a striking turn in a case that set off the largest automotive recall in United States history.
articles.byline: By Hiroko Tabuchi and Neal E. Boudette

articles.headline: The Other Kushner Brother’s Big Bet
articles.snippet: The family’s Trump connection is complicating life for Joshua Kushner, who has managed to keep a low profile while building his venture capital business.
articles.abstract: The family’s Trump connection is complicating life for Joshua Kushner, who has managed to keep a low profile while building his venture capital business.
articles.lead_paragraph: Just days after the 2016 presidential election, a young venture capitalist called an emergency staff meeting.

articles.headline: More VW Executives Could Be Charged, Court Documents Suggest
articles.snippet: Two suspects were conspicuously missing from the group of six Volkswagen executives indicted on Wednesday in the emissions scandal.
articles.abstract: Two suspects were conspicuously missing from the group of six Volkswagen executives indicted on Wednesday in the emissions scandal.
articles.lead_paragraph: The hunt for the people behind Volkswagen’s emissions scandal did not end with the company’s plea bargain this week.

articles.headline: S.E.C. Inertia on Paybacks Adds to Investor Harm
articles.snippet: The glacial pace of a Citigroup restitution plan raises questions about how “fair funds” are administered and who benefits from delays.
articles.abstract: The glacial pace of a Citigroup restitution plan raises questions about how “fair funds” are administered and who benefits from delays.
articles.lead_paragraph: When securities laws are broken and investors get hurt, the Securities and Exchange Commission often rides to the rescue, using its regulatory muscle to extract penalties that can be returned to victims.

articles.headline: House Clears Path for Repeal of Health Law
articles.snippet: The vote on a budget blueprint sets Congress on a course to fulfill a Republican promise to rescind the Affordable Care Act, President Obama’s signature domestic achievement.
articles.abstract: The vote on a budget blueprint sets Congress on a course to fulfill a Republican promise to rescind the Affordable Care Act, President Obama’s signature domestic achievement.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The House cleared the way on Friday for speedy action to repeal the Affordable Care Act, putting Congress on track to undo the most significant health care law in a half-century.
articles.byline: By Thomas Kaplan and Robert Pear

articles.headline: With a Major Oil Discovery, Guyana Is Poised to Become a Top Producer
articles.snippet: Exxon Mobil and Hess may soon confirm that the sea floor beneath the South American country’s coastal waters contains one of the richest energy discoveries in decades.
articles.abstract: Exxon Mobil and Hess may soon confirm that the sea floor beneath the South American country’s coastal waters contains one of the richest energy discoveries in decades.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Guyana, the tiny English-speaking South American country, is poised to become the next big oil producer in the Western Hemisphere, attracting the attention and investment dollars of some of the biggest oil companies in the world.

articles.headline: Head of Ethics Office Speaks Out. Some Republicans Ask, Was It Ethical?
articles.snippet: Walter M. Shaub Jr., after raising ethics concerns about the president-elect, has clashed with Republicans and is facing the threat of a congressional inquiry.
articles.abstract: Walter M. Shaub Jr., after raising ethics concerns about the president-elect, has clashed with Republicans and is facing the threat of a congressional inquiry.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Until recently, few had heard of Walter M. Shaub Jr. or the agency he leads, the Office of Government Ethics, viewed in Washington as an unloved but necessary barrier against ethical violations by federal appointees.
articles.byline: By Jennifer Steinhauer and Steve Eder

articles.headline: A Big Test for Big Batteries
articles.snippet: In California, an environmental crisis forced a utility to fast-track a risky idea — using rechargeable cells to stand in for power plants.
articles.abstract: In California, an environmental crisis forced a utility to fast-track a risky idea — using rechargeable cells to stand in for power plants.
articles.lead_paragraph: ESCONDIDO, Calif. — In Southern California in the fall of 2015, a giant natural gas leak not only caused one of the worst environmental disasters in the nation’s history, it also knocked out a critical fuel source for regional power plants.
articles.byline: By Diane Cardwell and Clifford Krauss

articles.headline: Jolted by Deaths, Obama Found His Voice on Race
articles.snippet: Tensions across the country prompted the president to abandon his early reticence on race again and again.
articles.abstract: Tensions across the country prompted the president to abandon his early reticence on race again and again.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Only weeks after 70 million Americans chose a black man for president, shattering a racial barrier that had stood for the entirety of the nation’s 232-year history, no one in the White House, especially the man in the Oval Office, wanted to talk about race.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear and Yamiche Alcindor

articles.headline: Scott Pruitt, Trump’s E.P.A. Pick, Backed Industry Donors Over Regulators
articles.snippet: If confirmed by the Senate, Mr. Pruitt could be in charge of policing industries that have long helped advance his political career.
articles.abstract: If confirmed by the Senate, Mr. Pruitt could be in charge of policing industries that have long helped advance his political career.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A legal fight to clean up tons of chicken manure fouling the waters of Oklahoma’s bucolic northeastern corner — much of it from neighboring Arkansas — was in full swing six years ago when the conservative lawyer Scott Pruitt took office as Oklahoma’s attorney general.
articles.byline: By Eric Lipton and Coral Davenport

articles.headline: ‘Marielitos’ Face Long-Delayed Reckoning: Expulsion to Cuba
articles.snippet: The migrants came to the U.S. by the thousands when Fidel Castro opened the Mariel port in 1980, and many took up a life of crime when they got here.
articles.abstract: The migrants came to the U.S. by the thousands when Fidel Castro opened the Mariel port in 1980, and many took up a life of crime when they got here.
articles.lead_paragraph: MIAMI — They were some of the most feared people in South Florida, men who became cinematic fodder and, long before Donald J. Trump uttered the term “bad hombres,” ones who really did give some immigrants a bad name.

articles.headline: Rich Chinese, Inspired by ‘Downton,’ Fuel Demand for Butlers
articles.snippet: Butler training programs have seen more recruits in recent years, and many point to “Downton Abbey,” the drama about British aristocrats, which was avidly watched in China.
articles.abstract: Butler training programs have seen more recruits in recent years, and many point to “Downton Abbey,” the drama about British aristocrats, which was avidly watched in China.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHENGDU, China — Mao once said that a revolution was not a dinner party. But with the communist revolution turning into opulent capitalism, China’s rich are now making sure the dinner party settings are immaculate and the wine is poured just right.
articles.byline: By Chris Buckley and Karoline Kan

articles.headline: World Leaders Push Israel and Trump to Forge a 2-State Deal
articles.snippet: Though peace efforts between Israel and the Palestinians seem doomed, world leaders gathered in Paris for a peace conference and signaled that they still longed for a solution.
articles.abstract: Though peace efforts between Israel and the Palestinians seem doomed, world leaders gathered in Paris for a peace conference and signaled that they still longed for a solution.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — An effort by France to give impetus to the stalled Israeli-Palestinian peace process through an international conference always faced long odds. But with an incoming American president who has vowed to support Israel no matter what, the project seemed even more quixotic.
articles.byline: By Alissa J. Rubin, Benoît Morenne and Isabel Kershner

articles.headline: Women’s March Gives Boost to Start-Up for Bus Sharing
articles.snippet: Skedaddle, which has an app that lets an individual create or join a trip on a chartered bus, will transport about 11,000 people to the march.
articles.abstract: Skedaddle, which has an app that lets an individual create or join a trip on a chartered bus, will transport about 11,000 people to the march.
articles.lead_paragraph: A few days after Donald J. Trump won the presidential election, the founders of Skedaddle, a bus start-up, began seeing some unusual activity.

articles.headline: ‘Catterbox’ Appealed to Owners’ Fondest Wish: A Chat With Tabby
articles.snippet: An ad for a pet treat, promoting a collar that renders cat sounds as human speech, was hugely popular. But does such a gizmo exist? Well, yes and no.
articles.abstract: An ad for a pet treat, promoting a collar that renders cat sounds as human speech, was hugely popular. But does such a gizmo exist? Well, yes and no.
articles.lead_paragraph: For months there has been excitement among the cat cognoscenti about the Catterbox, described in a viral video as “the world’s first talking cat collar.”

articles.headline: Bill Maher Isn’t High on Trump: The State of Free Speech in a New Era
articles.snippet: Mr. Maher, who has tested the limits of political criticism, is among many in Hollywood who fear that the president-elect’s critics will be targeted.
articles.abstract: Mr. Maher, who has tested the limits of political criticism, is among many in Hollywood who fear that the president-elect’s critics will be targeted.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif. — It was Nov. 12, and Bill Maher was about to begin his comedy act at the City National Civic in San Jose when he did something he hadn’t done in many years. He brought a drink with him to the stage; a standup roadie (tequila).

articles.headline: Tax Refund Loans Are Revamped and Resurrected
articles.snippet: Prior versions were seen as predatory and eventually vanquished. The newer kind are more customer-friendly, but consumer watchdogs remain wary.
articles.abstract: Prior versions were seen as predatory and eventually vanquished. The newer kind are more customer-friendly, but consumer watchdogs remain wary.
articles.lead_paragraph: Fast, free money. That’s what H&R Block, the nation’s largest tax-preparation chain, is advertising on giant banners outside its storefronts and in TV commercials featuring Jon Hamm of “Mad Men”: “You could get a refund advance of up to $1,250.” It is the first time in six years that the company has offered to front customers some money from their anticipated refund.

articles.headline: 2016 Was a Bad Year for Celebrity Deaths, by These Measures
articles.snippet: Confirming an unusual number of deaths in a given year is tricky, since celebrity is a subjective quality. But several media tallies point to a trend.
articles.abstract: Confirming an unusual number of deaths in a given year is tricky, since celebrity is a subjective quality. But several media tallies point to a trend.
articles.lead_paragraph: 2016 was a particularly bad year for celebrity deaths, judging by the many mourners on social media platforms like Twitter and Facebook. But verifying that the year was unusually lethal for stars is tricky.

articles.headline: With Guilty Plea, Takata Clears Way for a Likely Global Rescue
articles.snippet: The resolution of the U.S. criminal case against the Japanese company will result in a $1 billion fine, but also removes a cloud over its restructuring.
articles.abstract: The resolution of the U.S. criminal case against the Japanese company will result in a $1 billion fine, but also removes a cloud over its restructuring.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — With a $1 billion fine and a criminal guilty plea, Takata, the Japanese auto parts maker, took a major step on Friday toward putting the scandal over its deadly airbags behind it.

articles.headline: In Trump’s Feud With John Lewis, Blacks Perceive a Callous Rival
articles.snippet: Many blacks say the president-elect’s criticism of the civil rights leader shows a lack of understanding of the reverence with which they view the civil rights movement.
articles.abstract: Many blacks say the president-elect’s criticism of the civil rights leader shows a lack of understanding of the reverence with which they view the civil rights movement.
articles.lead_paragraph: Days before his inauguration, President-elect Donald J. Trump is engaged in a high-profile feud with some of the country’s most prominent African-American leaders, setting off anger in a constituency already wary of him after a contentious presidential campaign.

articles.headline: Workers Say Andrew Puzder Is ‘Not the One to Protect’ Them, but He’s Been Chosen To
articles.snippet: Donald J. Trump’s pick for labor secretary may soon be tasked with enforcing the very rules his company has been accused of violating.
articles.abstract: Donald J. Trump’s pick for labor secretary may soon be tasked with enforcing the very rules his company has been accused of violating.
articles.lead_paragraph: At first, Andrew F. Puzder’s California story sounds like one of the state’s sunny dreams come true: Midwestern lawyer stumbles into burger business, nurses storied chain back to health, wins industry plaudits and record profits.
articles.byline: By Jodi Kantor and Jennifer Medina

articles.headline: What to Make of the ‘Davos Class’ in the Trump Era
articles.snippet: The globalist elite gather in Switzerland to grapple with the world’s great challenges, but their relevance is in question in a time of Brexit and Trump.
articles.abstract: The globalist elite gather in Switzerland to grapple with the world’s great challenges, but their relevance is in question in a time of Brexit and Trump.
articles.lead_paragraph: DAVOS, Switzerland — President-elect Donald Trump has never been invited here. Neither has Nigel Farage, the British politician who led the Brexit campaign.

articles.headline: Trump Attacks BMW and Mercedes, but Auto Industry Is a Complex Target
articles.snippet: The globalized trade in vehicles, in which Detroit owns European brands and German cars come from Alabama, could make it hard to raise barriers.
articles.abstract: The globalized trade in vehicles, in which Detroit owns European brands and German cars come from Alabama, could make it hard to raise barriers.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — In his latest criticism of what he sees as unfair trade, Donald J. Trump has taken aim at German cars. Why, the president-elect asked a German newspaper, do so many well-heeled drivers in New York drive a Mercedes-Benz, while Germans buy so few Chevrolets?
articles.byline: By Keith Bradsher and Jack Ewing

articles.headline: Political Crisis Engulfs Samsung, a Firm Tied to South Korea’s Success
articles.snippet: Prosecutors have called for the arrest of Jay Y. Lee, the de facto head of Samsung, one of the country’s top companies.
articles.abstract: Prosecutors have called for the arrest of Jay Y. Lee, the de facto head of Samsung, one of the country’s top companies.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Samsung, the giant maker of products as varied as cargo ships and smartphones, is one of the driving forces of the South Korean economy. Now, the fate of its leadership could be tied to the sprawling investigation of a corruption scandal involving the nation’s president.
